metadata.title: Catalytic and Light-Driven ZnO/Pt Janus Nano/Micromotors: Switching of Motion Mechanism via Interface Roughness and Defect Tailoring at the Nanoscale

sections.heading: Catalytic and Light-Driven ZnO/Pt Janus Nano/Micromotors:
Switching of Motion Mechanism via Interface Roughness
sections.text: and Defect Tailoring at the Nanoscale

sections.heading: Amir Masoud Pourrahimi, Katherine Villa, Carmen Lorena Manzanares Palenzuela,
Yulong Ying, Zdeněk Sofer, and Martin Pumera*
sections.text:
The first models of mesoporous ZnO/Pt Janus micromotors that show fuelfree and light-powered propulsion depending on the interface roughness are shown. Two models of ZnO semiconducting particles with distinct surface morphologies and pore structures are synthesized by self-aggregation of primary nanoparticles and nanosheets into nanoscale rough and smooth microparticles, respectively. The self-assembled nanosheet model (smooth) provides a large surface for the formation of a continuous Pt layer with strong adherence, whereas the discontinuous Pt species take place inside the inter-nanoparticles pores in the self-assembled nanoparticle model (rough). The effects of the interface, surface porosity, defect, and charge transfer on the light-powered motion for both well-designed mesoporous ZnO/Pt Janus micromotors are investigated and compared to find the underlying propulsion mechanisms. The degradation of two model pollutants is demonstrated as a proof-of-concept application of these carefully engineered Janus micromotors. In this work, it is shown that by discreet material fabrication together with semiconductor/metal interface charge transport interpretation, it would be possible to develop new light-driven Janus micromotors based on other photocatalysts containing active surfaces such as TiO2.

transport, and release of drugs or cleaning agents in biomedical and environmental remediation applications, respectively.[2–8] The catalytic Janus nano/micromotors based on noble metals, e.g., platinum (Pt), which are autonomously propelled by decomposition of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), have been extensively used due to their simple design.[7,9] Although H2O2 is used as a common fuel in Fenton reactions for large-scale wastewater treatment, its use as a catalytic fuel for micromotors in biomedical applications might lead to a risk of introducing toxic species into living organisms.[10–12] The light energy source is renewable, powerful, and abundant, which meets the energy requirements for water purification,[11,13–19] and meanwhile it is harmless for living organisms.[13,16] Light not only can be converted into a directional motion by photoresponsive micromotors,[19] but it can also be applied to induce the photodegradation of different pollutants in water-purification processes.[11,16,20]
The autonomous self-propelled nano/micromotors, which are triggered by photochemical reactions, exploit different mechanisms for propulsion.[16,21] Among these mechanisms, the lightinduced nonelectrolyte gradients require a simple asymmetrical design for the micromotor, e.g., Janus morphology (two-faced). The motion by self-diffusiophoresis in the photocatalytic-based Janus micromotors can be changed to relatively steered motion toward the light source, where go/stop motions are detected during cycling illumination between on/off states.[22] In these systems, the semiconductive photocatalyst is often placed adjacent to a metal, providing enhanced photoexcited electron transfer at their interface, which results in an asymmetrical charge distribution around the Janus micromotor for its enhanced electrophoresis motion.[13,22–26] Understanding the underlying motion mechanism as a result of the photocatalyst/metal interfacial charge transfer is crucial for designing efficient semiconductive/ metal junctions at the nano/microscale. The heterojunctions not only affect the final motion, but also they can be used for more efficient photodegradation of pollutants in water resources.[27] As a result, Janus micromotors based on heavy and highly active photocatalysts such as ZnO can be designed to display enhanced directional and fast light-driven motion.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Self-motile nano/micromotors are small objects that can harvest various energies from different sources and convert them into motion.[1] The fact that these small-scale motors display active motion has allowed them to be used for either capture,
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1808678
1808678 (2 of 8) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
There are a few papers that show the influence of interface nanostructure on the motion of the catalytic nano/micromotors.[9,28–31] The mesoporous structure together with the interfaces has even been lesser addressed for the case of light-driven micromotors, which should play the dominant role on the selfpropulsion.[15,26] In this paper, we synthesize mesoporous ZnO/ Pt micromotor models with specific surface/interface morphologies to study their fuel-dependent propulsive behavior under light exposure (Scheme 1). The well-designed nanoscale rough and smooth micromotors based on self-assembly of, respectively, nanoparticles and nanosheets are shown as practical micromotor models in order to examine the underlying lightdriven propulsion mechanisms in relation to the porosity and surface/interface roughness. Accordingly, the optimized ZnO/ Pt nano/microstructures with tuned interfaces are designed to show controlled fuel-free and light-powered propulsion, while the high photocatalytic efficiency of two pollutant models, i.e., explosive and dye models, is maintained. We believe that the highlighted charge transport mechanisms at the interfaces can be applicable to other photocatalyst/metal heterojunctions especially for the TiO2 photocatalyst, due to its similarities with ZnO in terms of optical properties.

sections.heading: 2. Results and Discussion
sections.text:
Figure 1 depicts the fabrication of two ZnO/Pt Janus micromotor models with different surface morphologies at the nanoscale, which are designated as “rough” and “smooth.” Both as-synthesized ZnO microparticles, with sizes of ≈1 µm and specific surface areas (SSA) of ≈10 m2 g−1, were prepared through an entire scalable (4 g L−1) aqueous synthesis. The high concentration of LiOH precursor (highly alkaline medium) yielded “rough” ZnO microparticles, consisting of c-axisoriented primary zinc-enriched nanoparticles.[32,33] The lower LiOH concentration (near stoichiometric) gave hierarchical
“smooth” ZnO microparticles, which were self-assembled from primary nanosheets containing dominant oxygen-terminated crystal faces.[34] It should be noted that both ZnO microparticles have wurtzite crystal structures and mainly similar crystal habits to our previous studies.[33,34] By the physical vapor deposition (PVD) process, these pristine ZnO microparticles were asymmetrically coated with Pt, which took place within inter-nanoparticles regions and formed a thin layer on nanosheets for rough and smooth microparticles, respectively. The obtained Janus (two-faced) micromotors show different propulsion mechanisms under UV light exposure and H2O2 fuel, which are related to the surface/interface characteristics; see Scheme 1.
Figure 2 shows the nano/microstructure of “rough” ZnO/Pt micromotors as revealed by coupled scanning electron microscopy/energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM/EDX) characterizations accompanied by their motion assessment at different H2O2 fuel concentrations. The SEM images show that the primary 20–50 nm ZnO nanoparticles are assembled to ≈1 µm rough microparticles with inter-nanoparticle pores with

The Pt was not able to form a continuous layer with strong interfaces (adherence) at longer deposition times, as shown by the red arrow in the high-resolution SEM image, Figure 2d. It should be noted that longer deposition time shows more detached Pt species on the ZnO surfaces. It was shown that the high surface roughness and noncontinuous coverage of Pt in catalytic micromotors resulted in an enhanced translational propulsion using H2O2 fuel than that of Janus micromotors with continuous and smooth Pt coating.[29] Although our “rough” micromotors with noncontinuous coating showed fast directed propulsion using H2O2, they were not able to move faster under UV light irradiation without using H2O2; see Video S1 in the Supporting Information. These micromotors showed slightly enhanced motion under UV irradiation upon using H2O2.
The next step of our work is then to look into micromotors with smooth interfaces and high SSA (i.e., comparable to that of the “rough” particles). Figure 3a–e presents the “smooth” mesoporous ZnO/Pt Janus micromotors, where the primary building units of ZnO nanosheets provided large surfaces for Pt deposition. It is shown that the continuous deposition of Pt resulted in strong ZnO/Pt interfaces (adherence) that led to a light-driven and fuel-free motion. This continuous Pt deposition was performed onto the smooth nanosheet subsets of flower-shaped microparticles, which can be seen in the highresolution SEM image (Figure 3e, red arrows). It is worthwhile to mention that the amount of Pt is almost similar for both “rough” and “smooth” particles as revealed by EDX elemental percentage (Figure S1, Supporting Information).

The SSA of “smooth” particles (9.8 m2 g−1) is similar to that of the “rough” particles (10.3 m2 g−1). The surface area and the pore structure of both morphologies were examined by BET isotherms together with nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) pore size distribution, Figure 4. Both pristine model particles displayed isotherm type III according to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry classification with hysteresis loops having shapes close to both H3 and H4 types, suggesting the presence of slit-shaped pores (within micro- to macropore sizes)[32,34,36,37] (Figure 4a,b), while large mesopores (>5 nm) were detected by the NLDFT method[38] (Figure 4c,d). The “rough” particles show large pore volume in the range of 10–40 nm, which was also detectable in the highresolution SEM image shown in Figure 2d. Even though the “smooth” particles showed large pore volume within the pore size of ≈5 nm, the pore volume for the pores of >10 nm is lower than that of “rough” particles. The “smooth” particles also contain larger macropores (>50 nm) as shown in Figure 3a–e. This finding suggests that the ZnO surface mesopores of <10 nm are mainly suitable for smooth Pt deposition with strong interfaces via the PVD method.
The H2O2 fuel-dependent motion behavior for the light-driven “smooth” ZnO/Pt micromotors is shown in Figure 3f. These micromotors showed mainly Brownian motion with small displacements in pure water without UV light irradiation, whereas the nearly circular motion was detected after the micromotors were exposed to UV light. These smooth ZnO/Pt with smooth and large interfaces, therefore, have shown their potential for fuel-free and light-powered motion. These micromotors also showed the circular motion after addition of H2O2 regardless of UV light exposure, which indicates their fuel-independent motion behavior. The circular motion was not detected for the rough particles with rough surfaces, cf. Figures 2e and 3f.
Although there are some papers that address the effect of mesoporosity and nanoscale roughness on both light-driven and catalytic micromotors trajectories,[15,26,28,35] the effect of the hierarchical superstructure (above 1 µm) on the micromotor trajectories has been lesser addressed. It was suggested that large pores (in our case, the macropores among the nanosheets) are suitable for water fluid to take place in and alter the motion from linear to off-linear.[35] It should be noted that our hierarchical micromotors (smooth) have complex structures in terms of mass distribution, which changes its center of mass as compared to other uniform mass-distributed systems, i.e., “rough” ZnO/Pt motors. This finding hereby suggests that the circular motion is mainly related to the hierarchical superstructure of nanosheets subset, which was not detected for other Janus micromotors.
In order to assess the motion behavior of light-driven “smooth” micromotors, their MSD plots are shown in Figure 3g,h. In the absence of H2O2, the MSD plots show the linear correlation with time while the UV light was off, which indicates their Brownian motion. After exposure to UV light, the linear correlation switched to parabola for the time intervals shorter than rotational diffusion coefficient, i.e., Δt ≪ τR, which suggests that the diffusive motion was changed to directional motion; see Figure 3g. As time passes τR (0.68 s), the MSD starts to change from the parabolic to the linear relationship as the propulsion was again randomized.[28] The relatively randomized motion at longer times, i.e., Δt ≫ τR is displayed by incomplete circular motion in Figure 3f (H2O2-free and UV-on state). This change at Δt ≈ τR in the MSD plot (motion behavior) can be fitted to the linear-exponential correlation of Equation (3), which yields these experimental values: τR = 0.45 s, D = 1.6 µm2 s−1, and V = 3.3 µm s−1. After the addition of H2O2, the MSD for both UV-off and UV-on states showed parabola correlations with time, indicating their directional motion.

The effective diffusion coefficients and velocities were obtained by fitting into limiting forms of Equation (4), which are shown in Figure 3i,j. In the UV-off state, the “smooth” micromotors had a lower diffusion coefficient than that of “rough” particles at the low H2O2 level (<1 wt%). However, they exhibited an enhanced phoretic motion at the fairly high level of 3 wt% H2O2, cf. Figures 2g and 3i. This suggests that larger surfaces area of deposited Pt on ZnO nanosheets provides high decomposition efficiency of H2O2 for diffusiophoresis motion. In the UV-on state, the “smooth” micromotors showed fuelfree motion with an average velocity of ≈2.5 µm s−1, which was doubled after the addition of 3 wt% H2O2, Figure 3j. It has been reported that using H2O2 as an acidic medium forms atomic layers of zinc hydroxide[39] and ZnO2[9] on ZnO surfaces, and the new interfaces of ZnO/ZnO2/Pt alter the charge transfer at the semiconductor/metal junction.[40] Although the ZnO/Pt interface prior to H2O2 treatment exhibited Schottky contact, the addition of new ZnO2 phase into the interface enhanced the rectifying behavior for enhanced charge transport. The “smooth” micromotors without UV light also depicted slightly smaller velocities at 3 wt% H2O2 than that with UV light, which indicates that the UV light is not a dominant power source when using a high level of H2O2 fuel.
Since the main feature of “smooth” micromotors is their light-driven propulsion, it is meaningful to explore the charge transfer between the semiconducting ZnO photocatalyst and Pt metal under UV light exposure to shed light on the motion mechanism. Figure 5a,b shows, respectively, the UV–vis and photoluminescence (PL) spectra for “smooth” pristine particles before and after Pt deposition. Both ZnO and ZnO/Pt showed
an absorption peak at 366 nm assigned to ZnO bandgap, Figure 5a.[41] The intensity of absorption tails for the ZnO/Pt at longer wavelengths (360–500 nm) was larger than that of pristine particles, which indicates the interfaces between ZnO and Pt were well formed in the smooth micromotors.[24,41,42] The PL spectra (under an excitation wavelength of 360 nm) show a disappearance of the fluorescence peak at ≈560 nm after the introduction of Pt interfaces on ZnO nanosheets, indicating the removal (quenching) of ZnO surface defects. The emission peak at ≈560 nm (energy level of 2.2 eV) corresponds to the electron transfer from the conduction band to deep traps (oxygen vacancies in the ZnO crystalline boundaries and surface hydroxide defects).[34,43,44] The removal of this emission peak for ZnO/Pt micromotors, due to its strong interfaces, indicated that the surface defects were mainly suppressed.[41,42,45] This suggests that these defects, which might act as recombination and emission sites after light absorption/excitation, are reduced, and it can improve both photocatalytic activity and charge transfer in semiconductor/metal interfaces.
Figure 5c shows the charge transfer at the ZnO/Pt interfaces in the “smooth” micromotor together with its motion mechanism under UV light without using H2O2 fuel. In the presence of UV light, the photons are absorbed on ZnO surface and produce excited electrons, which transfer from valence band into conduction band and generate holes in the valence band. The electron– hole recombination, which occurred for pure ZnO due to its surface defects, is mostly hindered for ZnO/Pt micromotors. Therefore, there are more electrons available to transport from photocatalyst ZnO to Pt. However, it should be noted that the work function of ZnO is lower than that of Pt (WFZnO < WFPt), the energy band at the ZnO/Pt interface is bent upward, and a small Schottky barrier with the height of 0.35 eV is made.[41,46] In general, the electron/hole pair is generated at picosecond timescale, and these charges require nano- to microsecond timescale to transfer on the photocatalyst surface.[47] The lifetime of charges is not long enough and may recombine fast, whereas a cocatalyst (here is Pt) can enhance the charge separation by forming a Schottky junction with semiconductors. It was reported that the transfer of electrons from the semiconductive conduction band to the metal Fermi level might create interfacial states (defects) within the semiconductive bandgap,[41] which was not observed in our “smooth” ZnO/Pt micromotors PL spectra; see Figure 5b. This suggests that the Pt interfaces in the micromotors not only quench the ZnO surface defects, they also reduce the risk of additional interface defects, which may increase the deactivation of excited charges (i.e., electron and hole). The removal of “rough” ZnO surface defects was lower than that of “smooth” particles (see PL spectra in Figure S2 in the Supporting Information), which indicates the relatively stronger ZnO/Pt interface for the charge transfer in the case of “smooth” micromotors. Under UV-light exposure, the electrons transport from ZnO to Pt, and the holes left in the ZnO valence band decompose pure water into oxygen and protons at microsecond to second timescale.[22,47] The protons (H+) present in the medium are reduced to H2 over the Pt side; meanwhile, the protons migrate from the ZnO to the Pt side due to a proton concentration gradient. The proton migration produces a self-electro-osmosis flow for the propulsion of the Janus micromotors, while the proton gradient concentration also creates an electric dipole for asymmetrical

ZnO/Pt particles, which results in the electrophoresis motion due to the local electric field.
The decomposition of water on micromotor surfaces produces reactive oxygen species (ROS),[34] which together with the lightdriven propulsion can be used for efficient water-purification applications. Here, we show the photodegradation of explosive and dye pollutant models (i.e., picric acid and methyl orange, respectively) in pure water without using any H2O2, Figure 6. The UV–vis absorption peaks at 354 and 464 nm that are indicative of picric acid and methyl orange concentrations were used to assess the photodegradation efficiency of both micromotor models under UV light exposure; Figure S3 (Supporting Information). It is shown that the light-driven “smooth” micromotors have the higher photodegradation efficiency for both pollutant models as compared to “rough” micromotors. It should be noted that since the Pt species took place inside inter-nanoparticles regions and onto nanosheet surfaces, respectively, for “rough” and “smooth” microparticles, the particles with nanoscale roughness, therefore, have larger available ZnO surface area for the photodegradation. However, the higher motility of “smooth” micromotors in pure water under UV light is a prevailing factor for obtained larger photodegradation efficiency as compared to “rough” particles, which are not able to move faster under UV light.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusions
sections.text:
ZnO photocatalysts possess high photodegradation efficiency for the removal of a broad range of pollutants in water-purification applications. However, their use in the micromotors research area is limited due to their high density,
and low colloidal stability. Here we have synthesized two models of mesoporous ZnO/Pt Janus micromotors with high surface/volume ratio, which are, respectively, built up from primary nanoparticles and nanosheets, namely “rough” and “smooth” micromotors. It is shown that the Pt catalytic species take place inside the inter-nanoparticle regions with small interfaces for the particles with relatively high nanoscale roughness, whereas the smooth micromotor possesses thin Pt layers with strong interfaces onto the primary nanosheets. Even though the assembled nanoparticles ZnO/Pt micromotors (rough) showed enhanced diffusiophoresis motion using a fairly low level of H2O2 due to high Pt surface area, they were not able to move fuel free under UV irradiation. On the other hand, the self-assembled nanosheet micromotors (smooth) acquired strong interfaces between ZnO photocatalyst and Pt, which provided the fuel-free and light-driven propulsion. The Pt layer masks the ZnO surface defects arising from hydroxide species and oxygen vacancies in crystalline boundaries, which not only enhance the charge transfer at the interfaces but also minimize the electron–hole recombination rates. These two important features of the assembled nanosheets, which are obtained through nano/microstructure design and surface/ interface defect engineering, are suggested as the key factors to achieve fuel-less and light-driven ZnO-based micromotors. The importance of the nanoscale roughness at the interfaces could be applicable to other photocatalyst/metal heterojunctions with mostly similar optical properties such as TiO2/Pt and TiO2/Au. However, the latter example is controversial due to additional plasmonic effect of Au upon UV-light exposure. It is also important to examine the effect of semiconductive photo catalyst or metal atomic terminations on the heterojunctions charge transfer for obtaining enhanced electrophoresis motion. We believe that this matter, which is well-paid attention in photo catalysis communities, has not been widely addressed in the light-driven micromotors topic.

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Section
sections.text:
Materials: Lithium hydroxide (≥98%), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (≥98%), hydrogen peroxide (30%), methyl orange (dye content 85%), and picric acid (≥98%) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich.
Synthesis of Pristine ZnO Particles: As shown in Figure 1, different morphologies of ZnO particles were synthesized by water-based chemistry. 100 mL of either 1 m or 0.5 m lithium hydroxide aqueous solution was added to 300 mL of 0.067 m zinc nitrate aqueous solution, which resulted, respectively, in “rough” and “smooth” ZnO mesoporous particles. The reaction temperature was kept at 60 °C for 1 h.
Micromotor Synthesis: Aqueous suspension of ZnO particles was dropcasted on a glass slide, and Pt was then asymmetrically deposited on particles by the PVD method. The deposition was carried out by evaporation of ultrapure Pt slug using an e-beam evaporator with 9 kV voltage and 130 mA current at 10−6 mbar pressure. The ZnO/Pt Janus micromotors were detached from glass slide by ultrasonication in water for 5 min.
Characterizations of Pristine ZnO and ZnO/Pt Particles: A field-emission scanning electron microscope (TESCAN MAIA 3) connected to an energy dispersive spectrometer (Oxford Instruments, UK) was used to examine the particles’ morphology and their elemental mapping. BET N2 adsorption/desorption and the corresponding pore size distribution employing the NLDFT method (nitrogen adsorption on silica particles reference) were measured for pristine ZnO particles by NOVAtouch 2200 (Quantachrome, USA) at 77 K. The particles were first degassed at 200 °C
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2019, 1808678
1808678 (7 of 8) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
before BET measurement. The PL spectra were obtained by Fluorolog Extreme (Horiba, France) with a 450 W Xe lamp and a double excitation monochromator. The excitation wavelength was 360 nm. The UV–vis absorbance was recorded by a Multiskan Sky spectrophotometer, Thermo Scientific. The concentrations of ZnO and ZnO/Pt particles for both PL and UV–vis absorbance were adjusted to low concentrations of ≈10 mg L−1.
ZnO/Pt Micromotor Motion: An aqueous micromotor suspension (specific volume) with added H2O2 (with concentrations of 1, 3, and 5 wt%) was dropped on the glass slide. For capturing movies, an optical microscope (Olympus IX73) connected to a camera (Retiga R1 CCD) and OCULAR software was used. The UV light irradiation was carried out by 120 W mercury arc lamp (X-Cite 120Q excitation light source) connected to the optical microscope. The tracking of the micromotors was performed by Image Pro 9 software. The total time for taking the videos was 10 s with a frame-per-second (FPS) value of 8.3. The MSD calculation was carried out on time intervals of 0.12–1.08 s.
Fuel-Free Pollutant Photodegradation: The micromotors were suspended in aqueous solutions of picric acid and methyl orange, which were then illuminated by an Osram UV lamp (ULTRA VITALUX 300 W 230 V/E27). The remained pollutant concentration was obtained from the characteristic UV–vis absorbance peaks using a Multiskan Sky spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific). In particular, micromotor suspension together with pollutant solution (pollutant model 50 × 10−6 m, and micromotor; “rough”: 40 mg L−1 and “smooth” 25 mg L−1) was put in UV-transparent cuvettes. The suspension was later exposed to the UV light (the distance between the lamp and the cuvette was 30 cm).

metadata.abstractText: The first models of mesoporous ZnO/Pt Janus micromotors that show fuelfree and light-powered propulsion depending on the interface roughness are shown. Two models of ZnO semiconducting particles with distinct surface morphologies and pore structures are synthesized by self-aggregation of primary nanoparticles and nanosheets into nanoscale rough and smooth microparticles, respectively. The self-assembled nanosheet model (smooth) provides a large surface for the formation of a continuous Pt layer with strong adherence, whereas the discontinuous Pt species take place inside the inter-nanoparticles pores in the self-assembled nanoparticle model (rough). The effects of the interface, surface porosity, defect, and charge transfer on the light-powered motion for both well-designed mesoporous ZnO/Pt Janus micromotors are investigated and compared to find the underlying propulsion mechanisms. The degradation of two model pollutants is demonstrated as a proof-of-concept application of these carefully engineered Janus micromotors. In this work, it is shown that by discreet material fabrication together with semiconductor/metal interface charge transport interpretation, it would be possible to develop new light-driven Janus micromotors based on other photocatalysts containing active surfaces such as TiO2.
